Read More                        Required NYS Certification Exams            Important Information for NYS Teacher Certification Candidates Graduating May 2014 or After    The NYSED now requires that candidates applying for NYS Initial Certification on or after May 1st, 2014, complete new exams which are listed below, please see details from the NYSED website here and here as well as from the NYS Teacher Certification Examinations website here NYSED FAQ regarding the new exams requirements can be found here       Teacher Performance Assessment (edTPA) (not required for Speech and Language Disabilities)          Educating All Students Test (EAS)          Academic Literacy Skills Test (ALST)          Revised Content Specialty Test(s) (dual program completers will need two CSTs)       For details, please see New Exams Fast Facts below    The requirements for candidates graduating or applying for a certificate on or after May 1, 2014 are as follows:       All candidates for the Initial teaching certificate may take the current Content Specialty Test in their field. Candidates who do not pass the current CST prior to implementation of the new CST will have to pass the new CST.    Important Information for Early Childhood Ed and Childhood Ed majors (and for dual certification programs in these majors with Students with Disabilities).    Effective August 28, 2014, candidates who have not registered to take the previous version of the non-grade range specific Multi-Subject Test must register for the appropriate revised version of the Multi-Subject Tests.    Registration for the revised Multi-Subject Tests will open on August 28, 2014 and the first administration date will be September 22, 2014. If you have not passed the previous version of the Multi Subject Test by September 21, 2014, you must take the appropriate revised Multi-Subject Test. Please see grade range specific exams below:    Multi-Subject: Teachers of Early Childhood (Birth-Grade 2) (Field 211/212/245)    Multi-Subject: Teachers of Childhood (Grade 1-Grade 6) (Field 221/222/245)    Multi-Subject: Teachers of Middle Childhood (Grade 5–Grade 9) (Field    231/232/245)    Multi-Subject: Secondary Teachers (Grade 7–Grade 12) (Field 241/242/245)       Candidates who apply for their first Initial certificate on or after May 1, 2014—including candidates who will graduate from an approved teacher preparation program on or after May 1, 2014—should not take the LAST or the ATS‑W. These candidates will be required to pass the new Teacher Performance Assessment, Educating All Students test, and Academic Literacy Skills Test.    Candidates who apply for the initial SBL certificate on or after May 1, 2014—including candidates who will graduate from an approved SBL preparation program on or after May 1, 2014—should not take the current SBL exam. These candidates will be required to pass the new SBL exam and the new Educating All Students Test.       New Exams Fast Facts    edTPA    edTPA is a multiple measure assessment of teaching focused on student learning. Evidence of candidate teaching performance is drawn from a subject-specific learning segment: 3–5 lessons from a unit of instruction for one class of students. Teacher candidates submit authentic artifacts (lesson plans, video clips of instruction, student work samples) from their actual teaching during a clinical field experience. Candidates also submit commentaries that provide a rationale to support their instructional practices based on student learning strengths and needs. Candidates’ evidence is evaluated across five scoring components of teaching: Planning, Instruction, Assessment, Analysis of Teaching, and Academic Language.       Registration through NYU Steinhardt Office of Clinical Studies during student teaching , preparation materials at edTPA website edtpa.com    edTPA Frequently Asked Questions here    Fee $300    Minimum passing score determined by NYS is provided on edTPA website           Educating All Students (EAS)    The Educating All Students test consists of selected-response items and constructed-response items. Each constructed-response item will share scenario-based stimulus material with several selected-response items. The EAS test measures the professional and pedagogical knowledge and skills necessary to teach all students – diverse student populations, English language learners, students with disabilities - effectively in New York State public schools.       Offered Computer based    Register on NYSTCE website www.nystce.nesinc.com    Fee $102    Minimum Passing Score 520 (Score range 400-600)    Test Length - 2 hours, 15 minutes       Preparation materials on NYSTCE and NYSED websites below:    NYSTCE Preparation Homepage here    EAS Preparation Guide here    EAS Test Design and Framework here    EAS Webinar here under New York State Teacher Certification Exams    EAS Practice Test (Fee $29.95) here       Academic Literacy Skills Test (ALST)    The Academic Literacy Skills Test consists of selected-response items, two focused constructed-response items, and one extended written assignment. The ALST measures academic literacy skills – reading, writing to sources - necessary to teach effectively in New York State public schools.       Offered Computer based    Register on NYSTCE website www.nystce.nesinc.com    Fee $131    Minimum Passing Score 520 (Score range 400-600)    Test Length - 3 hours, 30 minutes       Preparation materials on NYSTCE and NYSED websites below:    NYSTCE Preparation Homepage here    ALST Preparation Guide here    ALST Test Design and Framework here    ALST Webinar here under New York State Teacher Certification Exams    ALST Practice Test (Fee $29.95) here        Content Specialty Tests (CSTs)    The CSTs (except those for languages other than English) consist of multiple-choice questions and a written assignment. The CSTs for languages other than English include recorded listening and/or speaking components and writing components. CSTs measure knowledge and skills in the content area of the candidate's field of certification .       Some offered computer based, some offered paper based    Register, preparation materials on NYSTCE website www.nystce.nesinc.com    Fee $119 - $179 computer based depending on exam, $79 paper based    Minimum Passing Score current CSTs 220 (score range 100-300), revised CSTs 520 (Score range 400-600)    Test Length - 4 hours to 5 hours 15 minutes depending on exam       Preparation materials on NYSTCE and NYSED websites below:    NYSTCE Preparation Homepage here    Preparation Guides here    Test Frameworks here    New CST Draft Frameworks here       Bilingual Education Assessments (BEAs)    The BEAs consist of multiple-choice questions and constructed-response assignments. They include recorded listening and speaking components in English and include listening, speaking, reading, and writing components in the target language. The BEAs are required of candidates seeking a bilingual education extension to a certificate.       Offered paper based    Register, preparation materials on NYSTCE website www.nystce.nesinc.com    Fee $79    Minimum Passing Score 220 (score range 100-300)    Test Length - 4 hours       Preparation materials on NYSTCE and NYSED websites below:    NYSTCE Preparation Homepage here    Preparation Guides here    Test Frameworks here       New Exam Requirements by program for Candidates Graduating May 2014 or after    Below please see the New York State Teacher Certification Exam (NYSTCE) requirements for each state approved certification program offered by NYU Steinhardt along with the corresponding NYS certificate(s).    *All paper based tests are are not available on all test dates, so please plan accordingly. Evidence of candidate teaching performance is drawn from a subject-specific learning segment: 3–5 lessons from a unit of instruction for one class of students. Teacher candidates submit authentic artifacts (lesson plans, video clips of instruction, student work samples) from their actual teaching during a clinical field experience. Candidates also submit commentaries that provide a rationale to support their instructional practices based on student learning strengths and needs. Candidates’ evidence is evaluated across five scoring components of teaching: Planning, Instruction, Assessment, Analysis of Teaching, and Academic Language.        MPAIA-GE 2029    Technology Resources for Performing Arts Education    Applications of communication and digital technologies as designed for performing arts as resources for performing arts educators. Special emphasis is given to the use of the World Wide Web (WWW) as a resource for researching and creating performing arts materials and developing collaboration in the performing arts. Applications of the WWW as an archive for performing arts materials and portfolios are also explored.          MPAIA-GE 2031    Collaborative Projects in Performing Arts    Projects developed collaboratively by performing artists, arts technicians, composers, choreographers, directors, and others designed for live and processed performance in various performance venues.          MPAIA-GE 2010    Human Development and Education in the Arts             MPAME-GE 2010    Current Readings in Music Education    A multi-disciplinary examination and application of the implications of critical theory for curriculum and pedagogy and the ways in which the educative environment can reflect this framework in music education. Particular attention will be paid to the performing arts and the ways in which our marginal status provides a powerful entry point into the conversation of 'general education.          MPAME-GE 2021    Music Reference and Research Materials             MPAME-GE 2027    The Teaching of Music in Junior and Senior High School    Music in the general curriculum. Developing an understanding and perception of the process of musical thought appplicable to youth. Students observe in selected schools.          MPAME-GE 2031    Creative Performance Opportunities in Music Education    Students serve as a production team that will create, rehearse, produce, and perform a culminating musical presentation at local venues. Such site may be schools, Senior Citizens Homes, Health Care Facilities, Community Centers. Students will assume the roles played by all personnel involved in putting on a performance, as well as becoming familiar with repertoire *music, lyrics, and dialogue) suited to the abilities of the performers.          MPAME-GE 2032    Music Education in a Cultural Context    Music's socio-ideological nature with special attention to: (a) the ways in which culture influences music education, music preference, music cognition, and musical values; and (b) the ways in which musical practices influence culture and social relations. Topics include: music education as intercultural education; music and gender; music and power; music as commodity; the educational implications of musical-cultural relativity; music education as an agent of social reproduction and transformation; music education as socialization process; music education as 'text'.          MPAME-GE 2033    Technological Trends in Music Education    Students create new work and music in the context of improvising, playing, composing, writing, moving, reflecting, meditating, and responding to the literature of creativity in the context of music education, composition, and the performing arts.          MPAME-GE 2034    Instrumental Techniques and Materials: Chamber Music    Rehearsal techniques and special problems in ensemble performance.          MPAME-GE 2035    Technological Trends in Music Education    The impact of music technology and its implications for music education are examined. Students are introduced to Digital Audio, MIDI (Music Instrument Digital Interface) and the use of MIDI in providing music scores for classroom and ensembles as well as the use of MIDI in live performance in student ensembles. Students focus on techniques of special applications of music technology to music education on the Web and other digital media.          MPAME-GE 2052    Community Music    C ommunity Music is an emerging field of music education that challanges many traditional assumptions and forms of music teaching and learning. This course examines the conceptual, cultural, historical, sociological and pedagogical foundations of community music from a global perspective. Students design the content for a computer-assisted instruction module at their level of service in their special areas of teaching music.          MPAME-GE 2058    Music Education Curriculum Development    The philosophical, psychological, sociological, political, and practical bases of music curriculum design. Students will learn to integrate curriculum theory and practice by applying their studies in this course to practical curriculum development projects for their individual teaching situations.          MPAME-GE 2061    Psychology of Music Education    This course analyzes a wide range of published research on relationships between music education and (1) behaviorism, (2) cognitive development thoery, (3) constructivism, (4) humanism, (5) human consciousness studies, (6) self-identity formation, (7) motivation theory, and (8) tests of musical intelligence and achievement. Music education contributes importantly to this dialectical exchange among competing and complementary theories.        MPAIA-GE 2029    Technology Resources for Performing Arts Education    Applications of communication and digital technologies as designed for performing arts as resources for performing arts educators. Special emphasis is given to the use of the World Wide Web (WWW) as a resource for researching and creating performing arts materials and developing collaboration in the performing arts. Applications of the WWW as an archive for performing arts materials and portfolios are also explored.          MPAIA-GE 2031    Collaborative Projects in Performing Arts    Projects developed collaboratively by performing artists, arts technicians, composers, choreographers, directors, and others designed for live and processed performance in various performance venues.          MPAIA-GE 2010    Human Development and Education in the Arts             MPAME-GE 2010    Current Readings in Music Education    A multi-disciplinary examination and application of the implications of critical theory for curriculum and pedagogy and the ways in which the educative environment can reflect this framework in music education. Particular attention will be paid to the performing arts and the ways in which our marginal status provides a powerful entry point into the conversation of 'general education.          MPAME-GE 2021    Music Reference and Research Materials             MPAME-GE 2027    The Teaching of Music in Junior and Senior High School    Music in the general curriculum. Developing an understanding and perception of the process of musical thought appplicable to youth. Students observe in selected schools.          MPAME-GE 2031    Creative Performance Opportunities in Music Education    Students serve as a production team that will create, rehearse, produce, and perform a culminating musical presentation at local venues. Such site may be schools, Senior Citizens Homes, Health Care Facilities, Community Centers. Students will assume the roles played by all personnel involved in putting on a performance, as well as becoming familiar with repertoire *music, lyrics, and dialogue) suited to the abilities of the performers.          MPAME-GE 2032    Music Education in a Cultural Context    Music's socio-ideological nature with special attention to: (a) the ways in which culture influences music education, music preference, music cognition, and musical values; and (b) the ways in which musical practices influence culture and social relations. Topics include: music education as intercultural education; music and gender; music and power; music as commodity; the educational implications of musical-cultural relativity; music education as an agent of social reproduction and transformation; music education as socialization process; music education as 'text'.          MPAME-GE 2033    Technological Trends in Music Education    Students create new work and music in the context of improvising, playing, composing, writing, moving, reflecting, meditating, and responding to the literature of creativity in the context of music education, composition, and the performing arts.          MPAME-GE 2034    Instrumental Techniques and Materials: Chamber Music    Rehearsal techniques and special problems in ensemble performance.          MPAME-GE 2035    Technological Trends in Music Education    The impact of music technology and its implications for music education are examined. Students are introduced to Digital Audio, MIDI (Music Instrument Digital Interface) and the use of MIDI in providing music scores for classroom and ensembles as well as the use of MIDI in live performance in student ensembles. Students focus on techniques of special applications of music technology to music education on the Web and other digital media.          MPAME-GE 2052    Community Music    C ommunity Music is an emerging field of music education that challanges many traditional assumptions and forms of music teaching and learning. This course examines the conceptual, cultural, historical, sociological and pedagogical foundations of community music from a global perspective.          MPAME-GE 2056    Problems of Music Education: Computer-Assisted Instruction    An examination of current strategies in using the computer as an aid to a learning in music education. Current music software, CD-ROM, and internet resources are examined and evaluated. Students design the content for a computer-assisted instruction module at their level of service in their special areas of teaching music.          MPAME-GE 2058    Music Education Curriculum Development    The philosophical, psychological, sociological, political, and practical bases of music curriculum design. Students will learn to integrate curriculum theory and practice by applying their studies in this course to practical curriculum development projects for their individual teaching situations.          MPAME-GE 2061    Psychology of Music Education    This course analyzes a wide range of published research on relationships between music education and (1) behaviorism, (2) cognitive development thoery, (3) constructivism, (4) humanism, (5) human consciousness studies, (6) self-identity formation, (7) motivation theory, and (8) tests of musical intelligence and achievement. Music education contributes importantly to this dialectical exchange among competing and complementary theories.          MPAME-GE 2082    Choral Materials and Techniques    T he choral rehearsal is more than just singing. This workshop provides hands-on experience with vocal and choral techniques, choral arranging and composition for various ensembles, including selection and development of repertoire, and involving students in the arranging, composing, and performing process.          MPAME-GE 2085    NYU Choral Arts Society    Performance of the major choral literature. The society presents concerts at many University and public functions. Smaller ensembles are derived from the total membership. MPAME-GE 2105    Woodwind Practicum for Music Education    An ensemble approach to teaching and learning woodwind instruments. MPAME-GE 2106    String Practicum for Music Education    An ensemble approach to teaching and learning string instruments. MPAME-GE 2108    Vocal Practicum for Music Education    Introduction to vocal techniques and materials with emphasis on vocal development at all grade levels, including the changing voice.          MPAME-GE 2111    Instrumental Conducting Practicum for Music Education    Practical procedures and materials for conducting instrumental ensembles at all levels of music education. MPAME-GE 2113    Music for Children    Music and movement experiences for the classroom (K-6); cognitive basis for aesthetic sensitivity and expression.          MPAME-GE 2114    Music for Exceptional Children    Music-movement experiences for individuals with mild to moderate impairment./dysfunction. MPAME-GE 2115    Instrumental Materials, Techniques, and Technology in Music Education    Instrumental materials and techniques suited to all levels of music instruction. Particular emphasis on assessment practices, diagnosis of instrumental problems, group methods, and individualized instruction including computer assisted technology.          MPAME-GE 2116    Teaching Music Composition and Improvisation    Teaching musical creativity in the middle and secondary school. MPAME-GE 2119    Teaching Music in the Elementary Grades    Integrated music and movement experiences in the development of elementary curricula for cognitive-affective growth. MPAME-GE 2149    Introduction to Orff and Kodaly Methods    Introduction to concepts and practices in the Orff and Kodaly methods for music education.
